item.title: Ethernet over Copper Reviving The Local Loop
item.description: Local loop usage has decreased as people switch from traditional phone lines to wireless or internet-based phone services. This has prompted some to suggest that these copper lines be completely removed. However, just as this idea emerges, new technology is giving these old lines a new purpose. item.title: Do You Need Bandwidth on Demand?
item.description: By: John Shepler When subscribing to bandwidth, you’re usually expected to understand your network’s needs and pick the optimal service. But what if your needs are unclear or fluctuate? What about transitioning from in-house IT to cloud-based services? What are the consequences of an incorrect choice? Traditional Bandwidth Services Fall Short Conventional line contracts offer fixed bandwidth for a predetermined period, like a DS3 connection providing 45 Mbps constantly. While this guarantees consistent speed, you pay even when it’s idle.

item.title: Fiber Optic vs Copper 50 Mbps
item.description: Businesses that need to connect numerous employees to the internet or move large files, particularly high-resolution images, require more bandwidth than a standard connection provides. Traditionally, they’ve upgraded their T1 lines to DS3 service, which offers 45 Mbps. Now, there are more choices for around 50 Mbps using both copper and fiber optic connections. DS3 is often considered a copper wireline service because it connects with coaxial cables and uses BNC connectors.
